subtitle: [Music]
New Thinking Allowed. Conversations on the
leading edge
of knowledge and discovery with
parapsychologist
Jeffrey Mishlove.
Hello and welcome. I’m Jeffrey Mishlove.
Today
I’d like to talk about Modernism and
Postmodernism.
I suppose to start out with I should
tell you,
I don’t see much difference between the
two of them. There are
people who will tell you that the
Postmodern movement is definitely
different than the Modern movement.
I think it’s true in some areas, such as
architecture. I remember
it’s been now, 30 or 40 years since I
interviewed the
great religious scholar Huston Smith
about his book, Beyond the Post-Modern
Mind. He made a point of telling me, from his
perspective,
he saw very little difference between
Modernism and
Postmodernism. I’m going to go
along with that
viewpoint of Huston Smith’s, and
hopefully you’ll see why by the time I
come to the end
of this monologue.
I should say, and you probably, most
of you, understand that I have a very unique
education. I created my own individual
interdisciplinary doctoral major at the University
of California, Berkeley, in Parapsychology.
I have the only
diploma, to my knowledge, ever awarded by
an accredited university
that actually says “Parapsychology”
right on the diploma. One of the unique
features of my particular journey
through academia is that, almost
without exception, every time I
encountered
a really great professor, they
either quit or got fired.
That includes a fellow named
Carrie Prescott – or Carigan Prescott.
I took his course in “Theatre of the Absurd.”
It was a wonderful course. One of the
things that he explained is that the
“Theatre of the Absurd,” which began
towards the end of the 19th century,
coincided with the
development of psychological theories of
the unconscious mind.
All of a sudden you find, in the “Theatre
of the Absurd,” things that are reflecting
dream reality, jumping from one thing to
another. Talking about things that were
previously unmentionable, a great example is
the first Absurd Play “Ubu Roi”
or “King Ubu.”
It’s been repeated in many different
ways, and
in many different forums, subsequently, but
you get the idea of this tyrannical
ruler who was
mucking around in his own excrement. It
reminds me quite a bit of the political
leader of the United States, presently, but that’s
another matter. We live in absurd times.
I think the point is, if you look at
“Theater of the Absurd,” it’s one example of
the Modernism-Postmodernism movement
along with modern art, along with changes
in architecture, and in particular music.
Music has gone through enormous changes,
just enormous, over the last hundred
years. What we see in all of these
examples, to my way of thinking, is an
effort to get at
what’s underneath the scabs of modern
culture. In other words, not to be satisfied with
reality as it’s been handed down to us
by our ancestors. The sort of Victorian
world where the Queen is in her
castle and
God is up in heaven, and all's right
with the
world, the Empire is mighty and
prosperous.
That all broke down for a hundred
different reasons.
Today, if you
read all the comments posted on
the New Thinking Allowed interviews,
people coming from every perspective
explaining
one way or another why they are so
dissatisfied with what we
call reality.
The Postmodern and Modern movements
reflect this. It’s an opportunity, one might say,
to make the unconscious conscious – which
is a great project –
so that we can be aware of the things
that we’ve been hiding
from ourselves.
Certainly, the theater
exemplifies this. Here’s another
example though,
of it. Many, many years ago, well
over 20 years ago, I interviewed
Dr. Leonard Shlain, who had written a book
called The Alphabet Versus the Goddess.
He described something that he thinks
happened to human consciousness
when the alphabet was invented.
That goes back a long time ago, maybe
3,000 - 4,000 years ago
in human culture. He suggests that prior
to that time
people thought in visual images and
expressed themselves
in visual images, but the alphabet itself
became linear. Rather than,
as images are more than linear, at least
they’re planar – they express a plane –
if not a complete three-dimensional
model of reality. But the alphabet
itself is, you know, letter by letter,
word by word. Just as I’m speaking to you
now. I’m not trying to use poetical imagery
or metaphors or
jumping around. I am trying to pursue more
or less a logical
train of thought; that’s part of the age
in which we live.
And it’s an age that’s been going on
ever since the
first writing appeared. When we switched
over from
hieroglyphs and pictograms and rock
paintings, for example, to an alphabet.
He said it really changed the brains
of people, and as a result of that he
points out that
images became forboden.
In particular, for example, in Islam,
where for the most part – there have been
some wonderful exceptions to that – but
painting was illegal.
In Judaism as well,
there are some images that appear in a
synagogue but for the most part,
inside of Judaism, images are forbidden.
The Catholic Church, of course, has many,
many images but
Shlain suggests that
there was a reawakening of the
imaginal capacity of humans to think in
images and that happened with the
development of photography.
All of a sudden, everybody now has
their camera. Everybody works with images
and even video.
So that expresses a kind of
awakening, and one might say as
dark and disgusting as some
aspects of modern art and music
and theatre can become they seem to, in
many ways, express alienation,
anxiety, bitterness –
the dark side of human
nature that’s been hidden for so long.
It also expresses a kind of an
awakening.
They go hand in hand at times.
The Creator and the Destroyer. The
Destroyer of all the old memes
is also, in some way, the Creator of the
new ones.
That’s what we’re witnessing in this
very turbulent period in which we exist.
I suppose – to add fuel to the fire –
the period of Modern Art and
Postmodern Art also coincides with
the development of Modern Physics. The
idea “the Indeterminacy Principle.”
You look at Cubist paintings, you see
things from many
angles at once, and things do
seem a little bit indeterministic,
or a lot indeterministic. Futuristic art
also coincides with the
development of new technology. So, you
had a new psychology. You had
new sciences. You had new physics. And you
had two major World Wars,
expressing great disillusionment
about what has society become.
I’ve expressed this before in a
previous monologue.
The 20th century with its two
major World
Wars – enormous famines, enormous
dislocations and revolutions – in some
ways represents a low point
in all of human history.
But out of that low point is the
potential for something
new. Something better. Something
different. I’m reminded of a poem
by T.S.
Eliot, clearly an exemplar in the
field of literature in the Modernist-
Postmodernist
Movement. In his classic poem “Four
Quartets,” the last poem in which he
says this: “We shall not cease
from exploration And the end of
all our exploring Will be to arrive
where we started And
know the place for the first time.”
If you think about that
in a cultural sense, where we started, the
earliest, most
archaic principles
of humanity were what you could think of
as animism:
the idea that everything is alive,
that everything is conscious – the rocks,
the trees.
Consciousness is everywhere.
Everything has
spiritual essence embedded in it.
That’s where we started. If we could
arrive
there only to recognize it for the first
time, to really understand it,
that would seem to be the goal of
all of this
blooming, buzzing confusion in which
we’re living.
I’d like to think that that project is
really at the root – at the heart – of the
New Thinking Allowed
channel. So, let me conclude
by asking you to think about this
question: Where do you stand in
relationship to the
Modernist Movement, to the Postmodernist
Movement?
Do you think of yourself as someone with
a more classical, a romantic, a Victorian
sensibility?
Do you think of yourself as a decadent
personality? Are you wrapped up in the
occult? Are you caught up in
conspiracy thinking?
Are you a Futurist? Are you an
up-winger? – as my friend Jason
probably would characterize himself.
How do you relate to the modern world?
I’ll leave you with that thought, and
thank you,
once again, for being with me.
